prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity:
Bothwell et al. (2013) found a typical line flux of SMGs of the order of >2 mJy and line FWHM of 500 km/s. Hence, we request the rms per 200 km/s channels of ~0.7 mJy to obtain >3 sigma detections per channel (higher at the peak). Some SMGs show slightly fainter fluxes and wider line width, so for these cases we will smooth the spectrum further to find significant detections.
In order to guarantee 2 CO lines at z>2.5 (Fig 3) we request a spectral scan at band 3 covering 84.2 - 111.2 GHz and at band 4 covering 125.2 - 152.2 GHz (four tuning at each band).
This corresponds to 2-3 min on source per tuning and a total integration time for 11 sources of 8.8 hr including calibration. This was calculated with the OT assuming an average weather condition of precipitable water vapour of 5.186 mm (7th octile) for band 3 and 2.748 mm (6th octile) for band 4.
Imaging requirements:
Our targets have optical sizes <~1'' (8 kpc at z=3-5). As we plan a detection experiment, we opt for the spatial resolution of ~2'' in order not to resolve the targets.
Correlator setup:
In order to achieve the best possible sensitivity we will use the dual polarisation mode. We selected the time division mode (TDM) with spectral resolution of 60-90 km/s to limit the data rate. Our expected line widths are a few times larger.
Calibration: Default
Bandpass accuracy: Standard
Scheduling/time constraints: None
Data rate: Normal
Special constraints on standard observing modes: Our targts are relatively bright, which transform in just 2 min of integration time per source per tuning. This results in significant overheads. This is the only efficient way to derive redshifts for submm-bright galaxies, as longer integration time per source are not required.
THe same as in the first Science Goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Submm-selected galaxies (SMGs) provide a unique way to study the dust-obscured star-formation activity in the Universe, because such dusty galaxies are missed in optical surveys and their properties provide important constraints on galaxy formation models. Here we propose to obtain the first 100% complete redshift distribution of a statistically significant flux-limited sample of such galaxies. This was not possible before because 1) previous SMG samples were largely incomplete below fairly bright flux levels; 2) redshift completeness was usually low. Due to the unprecedented data quality delivered by SCUBA2 and the excellent COSMOS supporting data, our sample of 53 SMGs is 95% complete at 2.5 mJy and we have redshift information for 80% of them. Our aim is to measure CO redshifts for the remaining 11 sources. The resulting luminosity function will for the first time enable us to measure accurately their contribution to cosmic star formation (~2 mJy SMGs contribute more significantly to cosmic star-formation density than their brighter cousins). Moreover, the number of very distant SMGs (likely dominating our target sample) provides important constraints on galaxy evolution models.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
